UNDERSTANDING DISEASE: AN INTEGRATED APPROACH

Rationale
Change in teaching staff member
Blurb
Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"Students will develop independent learning and self-evaluation skills"
How this is developed:
"By independent guided reading of suggested texts and primary literature"

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
"Become proficient in applying interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary approaches to understanding biological systems and processes;"
How this is developed:
"The module is designed to be interdisciplinary by nature, cutting across the traditional Biomedical subjects such as Physiology, Pharmacology and Biochemistry. Student will have to engage with this content. "

Skill/Other Attribute 3:
"Be able to synthesise information and form a coherent understanding"
How this is developed:
"Through the taught elements of the course"
Educational Aims
To provide students with knowledge of the mechanistic basis of selected diseases, including relevant biochemistry, physiology, pharmacology, cell signalling and pathophysiology;

To develop in students an understanding of the basis for current therapies for selected diseases, and to allow students to review and critique novel treatments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will cover selected diseases which will be discussed in terms of a number of clearly-identified processes from the clinical presentation of the disease to our understanding of the underlying anatomy, physiology, pathology, and current therapies.

Successful students will achieve an integrated and cross-disciplinary understanding of disease processes.  They will also attain a knowledge of current thinking on the underlying cause of each disease and how scientific tools can be used to develop novel approaches for new treatments. Students will be required to think across the various disciplines they have studied at Level 4 and 5 in their quest to understand disease mechanisms.

The module will be taught by lectures and tutorials and it will be assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will cover a number of diseases which exemplify different underlying mechanisms and which are aligned with the research interests of those teaching on the module. In some cases the material will link in to what you have learned in previous modules, for instance second year modules on Virology, The Multicellular Organism, Cell Signalling in Health and Disease, and Regulatory and Neurophysiology.

Examples of conditions we will consider may include:

HIV/AIDS.

The lectures will cover the epidemiology of HIV/AIDS; symptoms and diagnosis of the disease; modes of transmission; pathophysiology; life cycle of HIV and milestones within the HIV life cycle for therapeutic exploitation; pharmacotherapy and viral resistance. It will discuss the current clinical management of HIV and our understanding of the long-term complications of both the disease and the therapy used. It will introduce the basic concept of pharmacogenomics and discuss how that is made use to personalise patient treatment in HIV/AIDS.

Osteoarthritis.

OA is a chronic disease associated with the degeneration of tissues within synovial joints such as the hips and knees. Characteristics of the disease are erosion of the articular cartilage within the joints, inflammation of the synovial lining and pathological changes to other joint structures such as the anterior cruciate ligament and the menisci. The disease is multifactorial with genetic and environmental contributory factors and is strongly associated with age. This topic will cover the structure of the key tissues in the synovial joint at the cellular and molecular level, will identify the key molecular mechanisms that promote cartilage destruction during osteoarthritis and will highlight current limitations in treatment of the disease.

Epilepsy.

Current concepts underlying the pathogenesis of epilepsy will be introduced, and the mechanism by which drug therapies work at the molecular level will be examined. In particular the role of individual variability in responses to therapeutic agents will be discussed.

Hypertension.

Hypertension is a very common disease characterised by an increase in systemic blood pressure, and is a major risk factor for many conditions including stroke, myocardial infarction, vascular aneurysm, and heart failure. It is known as a silent killer, because it is generally without obvious symptoms and often remains undiagnosed. Pathophysiology is complex, with both genetic and environmental contribution and a positive correlation with increasing age.
This lecture block will introduce some of the causes and theories of hypertension. Multiple pharmacological and lifestyle strategies are available to control hypertension, and these will be discussed along with some recent novel approaches for treatment of this dangerous condition.

Pancreatitis.

Pancreatitis is a common yet difficult to treat medical problem involving pathological destruction of pancreatic acinar cells, the cells responsible for secretion of pancreatic enzymes into the digestive tract. A major mechanism in the development of pancreatitis appears to be disruption of calcium signalling. In this block of lectures we will discuss the cellular events underlying the pathophysiology of the condition, as well as the impact of discoveries made at a cellular level on informing novel avenues for treatment.

Learning resources linked to the module content including lecture PowerPoints, streamed lectures, appropriate references and library resources will be provided via a module Canvas site. You will be expected to use these references to support your own learning and you may also need to do independent research to understand the lecture material.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Synchronous Online Lecture
Description: Lectures will provide a framework for understanding the underlying mechanistic basis for the diseases being covered in the module. Lectures will also be used to communicate the evidence base for the various diseases. Lecturers will identify and suggest potential areas for extra reading.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Formative Feedback (e.g. revision sessions) Description: Revision and feedback for in-course assessment Attendance Recorded: Yes

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 3 - Self-directed learning
Description: Self-directed learning aided by directed online resources.
Attendance recorded: No

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The in-course assessment will test the students' knowledge and understanding of the content across the range of subjects studied in the module. The final assessment will also be designed to test knowledge and understanding, but will contain a greater element of synthesis and evaluation of material across the module. The format of both assessments will be open-book essay.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency and confidence in our students. Skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"Students will develop independent learning and self-evaluation skills"
How this is developed:
"By independent guided reading of suggested texts and primary literature"

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
"Become proficient in applying interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary approaches to understanding biological systems and processes;"
How this is developed:
"The module is designed to be interdisciplinary by nature, cutting across the traditional Biomedical subjects such as Physiology, Pharmacology and Biochemistry. Student will have to engage with this content. "

Skill/Other Attribute 3:
"Be able to synthesise information and form a coherent understanding"
How this is developed:
"Through the taught elements of the course"
Educational Aims
To provide students with knowledge of the mechanistic basis of selected diseases, including relevant biochemistry, physiology, pharmacology, cell signalling and pathophysiology;

To develop in students an understanding of the basis for current therapies for selected diseases, and to allow students to review and critique novel treatments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will cover selected diseases which will be discussed in terms of a number of clearly-identified processes from the clinical presentation of the disease to our understanding of the underlying anatomy, physiology, pathology, and current therapies.

Successful students will achieve an integrated and cross-disciplinary understanding of disease processes.  They will also attain a knowledge of current thinking on the underlying cause of each disease and how scientific tools can be used to develop novel approaches for new treatments. Students will be required to think across the various disciplines they have studied at Level 4 and 5 in their quest to understand disease mechanisms.

The module will be taught by lectures and tutorials and it will be assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will cover a number of diseases which exemplify different underlying mechanisms and which are aligned with the research interests of those teaching on the module. In some cases the material will link in to what you have learned in previous modules, for instance second year modules on Virology, The Multicellular Organism, Cell Signalling in Health and Disease, and Regulatory and Neurophysiology.

Examples of conditions we will consider may include:

HIV/AIDS.

The lectures will cover the epidemiology of HIV/AIDS; symptoms and diagnosis of the disease; modes of transmission; pathophysiology; life cycle of HIV and milestones within the HIV life cycle for therapeutic exploitation; pharmacotherapy and viral resistance. It will discuss the current clinical management of HIV and our understanding of the long-term complications of both the disease and the therapy used. It will introduce the basic concept of pharmacogenomics and discuss how that is made use to personalise patient treatment in HIV/AIDS.

Osteoarthritis.

OA is a chronic disease associated with the degeneration of tissues within synovial joints such as the hips and knees. Characteristics of the disease are erosion of the articular cartilage within the joints, inflammation of the synovial lining and pathological changes to other joint structures such as the anterior cruciate ligament and the menisci. The disease is multifactorial with genetic and environmental contributory factors and is strongly associated with age. This topic will cover the structure of the key tissues in the synovial joint at the cellular and molecular level, will identify the key molecular mechanisms that promote cartilage destruction during osteoarthritis and will highlight current limitations in treatment of the disease.

Epilepsy.

Current concepts underlying the pathogenesis of epilepsy will be introduced, and the mechanism by which drug therapies work at the molecular level will be examined. In particular the role of individual variability in responses to therapeutic agents will be discussed.

Hypertension.

Hypertension is a very common disease characterised by an increase in systemic blood pressure, and is a major risk factor for many conditions including stroke, myocardial infarction, vascular aneurysm, and heart failure. It is known as a silent killer, because it is generally without obvious symptoms and often remains undiagnosed. Pathophysiology is complex, with both genetic and environmental contribution and a positive correlation with increasing age.
This lecture block will introduce some of the causes and theories of hypertension. Multiple pharmacological and lifestyle strategies are available to control hypertension, and these will be discussed along with some recent novel approaches for treatment of this dangerous condition.

Pancreatitis.

Pancreatitis is a common yet difficult to treat medical problem involving pathological destruction of pancreatic acinar cells, the cells responsible for secretion of pancreatic enzymes into the digestive tract. A major mechanism in the development of pancreatitis appears to be disruption of calcium signalling. In this block of lectures we will discuss the cellular events underlying the pathophysiology of the condition, as well as the impact of discoveries made at a cellular level on informing novel avenues for treatment.

Learning resources linked to the module content including lecture PowerPoints, streamed lectures, appropriate references and library resources will be provided via a module Canvas site. You will be expected to use these references to support your own learning and you may also need to do independent research to understand the lecture material.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Synchronous Online Lecture
Description: Lectures will provide a framework for understanding the underlying mechanistic basis for the diseases being covered in the module. Lectures will also be used to communicate the evidence base for the various diseases. Lecturers will identify and suggest potential areas for extra reading.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Formative Feedback (e.g. revision sessions) Description: Revision and feedback for in-course assessment Attendance Recorded: Yes

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 3 - Self-directed learning
Description: Self-directed learning aided by directed online resources.
Attendance recorded: No

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The in-course assessment will test the students' knowledge and understanding of the content across the range of subjects studied in the module. The final assessment will also be designed to test knowledge and understanding, but will contain a greater element of synthesis and evaluation of material across the module. The format of both assessments will be open-book essay.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency and confidence in our students. Skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
